Dear Student_E,

Thank you for your continued patience and for asking directly.

At this stage, we cannot confirm individual students’ match status or whether any specific higher-priority student is “expected” to apply. What I can share is the decision rule we are following: with one seat remaining, we will continue to hold that seat for the possibility of an application from a higher-priority student (Student_A, Student_B, Student_C, or Student_D) in a later round.

The condition under which we would be able to consider you is: if we reach a later point in the process and the seat is still unfilled *and* no higher-priority student applies to School_C by then, we would reassess and may be able to extend an offer.

If you wish, you may check back again in a later round; if circumstances change and we are able to release the seat, we will respond accordingly.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_E,

Thank you for your thoughtful question.

Because admission is determined strictly by our priority order and we have only one remaining seat, we cannot set a specific earlier “release round” (or conditional on other students finalizing elsewhere) that would trigger us to offer the seat to a lower-priority applicant. Our rule is simple: we keep the seat available as long as there remains a possibility that a higher-priority student (Student_A, Student_B, Student_C, or Student_D) may apply in a later round.

Practically, the meaningful time to submit another formal [APPLY] would be very late in the process (near the end of the market, e.g., the final few rounds). If by that point the seat is still open and no higher-priority student has applied to School_C, then we would reassess and could extend an offer to fill the seat.

I understand that is not a firm guarantee, but it is the most accurate guidance we can provide under the rules of this process.

Sincerely,
School_C Admissions
